channel.title: Mastodon Home Timeline
channel.description: RSS feed for the Mastodon Home timeline

item.title: PsychoPy
item.description: Did you know we make all of the materials from our workshops and downloadable as power point /pdfs? Please feel free to reuse anything in your teaching! #opensciencehttps://workshops.psychopy.org/#open_materials

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
Neural Ensembles in the Lateral Prefrontal Cortex Temporally Multiplex Task Features During Virtual Navigation
https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2024.01.10.574378v1
#neuroscience

item.title: Dr Emma Kate Ward
item.description: I've easily found tech people on Mastodon but it's been harder to find #psychology and #neuroscience people, and I've noticed I followed mostly men, too. I've been consciously following new people when I see boosts, but it's really slow.Then I found this tool, which finds people who are followed by people you follow, based on public information (so no permissions required!). Really nice way to get more of a diverse feed.(And if I've just followed you today, hi!)https://followgraph.vercel.app/

item.title: Sainsbury Wellcome Centre
item.description: In a new Q&A, Dr @AliceCMo (Columbia University‚Äôs Zuckerman Mind Brain and Behavior Institute) discusses her ENSS experience at SWC and what drives her research on solving the credit assignment problem in the context of a complex multi-dimensional action.‚ÄúMy current research studies how we learn new movements. The goal is to understand how different parts of the brain are relevant for learning different aspects of a specific skill.‚ÄùRead more: https://www.sainsburywellcome.org/web/qa/reaching-rewards-how-spatial-targets-are-learned

item.title: PsychoPy
item.description: Ever fancied just part of our three day official workshop? We now run specific "Topics" workshops. Each workshop samples part of our three day workshop, so that you can pick and choose content for your interests. You can book tickets or apply for waivers here üëá https://workshops.psychopy.org/topics.html

item.title: Steven Strogatz
item.description: The third edition of my textbook, Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos, was published today. You can preview the first 68 pages on Google Books, or take a look at the preface below to see what's new. The main new thing is a chapter on the Kuramoto model! Hope you enjoy it.

item.title: Mike Knell
item.description:
Non-resident British citizens, provided they have at least one previous address in the UK, can register to vote here regardless of how long they've been living abroad. Go and do it now!
https://www.gov.uk/register-to-vote

item.title: Holeintheheadesign
Boris Barbour
item.description: Preach.https://pluralistic.net/2024/01/17/monopolies-produce-billionaires/#inequality-corruption-climate-poverty-sweatshops

item.title: Spencer LaVere Smith
item.description: Synopsys buying Ansys is wild. Code V and Zemax OpticStudio would be under the same roof. It's like Apple and Microsoft merging. Or DC and Marvel. Or Airbus and Boeing (actually they could do worse). https://www.ansys.com/news-center/press-releases/1-16-24-synopsys-acquires-ansysThere's a bit more competition in the silicon design space, so maybe regulators will let it go through. But in optics, it looks like it would be a monopoly.

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description:
The tusks of mammoths and mastodons contain a daily journal of their wanderings. Only now are scientists reading them. Here‚Äôs my story on how these elephantine biographies are offering clues about their lives and ultimate extinctions. Gift link:
https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/17/science/woolly-mammoth-tusk-research.html?unlocked_article_code=1.OU0.t4b3.w0SYqE_zduOw&smid=url-share

item.title: Dorothy Bishop
item.description:
great story of a sting operation that exposed dodgy journal publishing anti LGBTQ+ nonsense
https://retractionwatch.com/2024/01/17/the-singapore-sting-why-an-activist-published-a-fake-paper-on-lgbtq-child-acceptance/
#misinformation #sting

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
New paper! A universal pattern of brain wave frequencies. They are slower in deep cortical layers and faster in superficial layers. When something is this ubiquitous, you know it is doing something important.
https://picower.mit.edu/news/study-reveals-universal-pattern-brain-wave-frequencies

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
The findings support a model suggesting that the brain uses high-frequency oscillations to incorporate new information while existing memories and control processes are maintained by low-frequency oscillations.
See: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuron.2018.09.023
